q: What are the main ways to catch brucellosis?
a: Brucellosis is mainly caught by drinking unpasteurised milk, eating dairy products made from unpasteurised milk, eating raw or undercooked meat, or from contact with bodily fluids of farm animals.

q: What are the symptoms of brucellosis?
a: Symptoms of brucellosis include high temperature, loss of appetite, sweating, headaches, extreme tiredness, back and joint pain.

q: When should I see a GP if I have symptoms of brucellosis?
i: If you have symptoms of brucellosis and have had unpasteurised milk or dairy products, eaten raw or undercooked meat, or work closely with farm animals, you should see a GP.
a: You should see a GP if you have symptoms of brucellosis and have had unpasteurised milk or dairy products, eaten raw or undercooked meat, or work closely with farm animals. Also, inform your GP if you have recently travelled overseas.

q: How is brucellosis diagnosed?
a: Brucellosis is usually diagnosed using a blood test.

q: How is brucellosis treated?
a: Brucellosis is treated with a course of antibiotics for at least 6 weeks. It's important to finish the entire course.

q: Will brucellosis come back after treatment?
a: After completing the treatment, you should make a full recovery and the infection is unlikely to return.

q: What can I do to avoid getting brucellosis?
a: To reduce your chances of getting brucellosis, avoid contact with livestock and wild animals in places where brucellosis is a problem. Wear protective clothing when working with animals and put a plaster on any wounds before touching animals. Also, do not drink unpasteurised milk, eat dairy products made from unpasteurised milk, or eat raw or undercooked meat.

q: What should I do if I suspect I have brucellosis?
a: Brucellosis is a notifiable animal disease. If you suspect you or someone you know has it, you must report it immediately by calling the Defra Rural Services Helpline on 03000 200 301.

q: Is there a human vaccine against brucellosis?
a: No, there is no human vaccine against brucellosis.
